title: Grade 8 English Language Arts
teaser: The overarching focus for all modules is on building students’ literacy skills as they develop knowledge about the world.

children.title: Finding Home: Refugees
children.teaser: Students will develop their ability to read and understand complex text.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: War Coming Close to Home
children.teaser: Students will build their close reading skills as they consider the crisis of war coming close to home.

children.title: Making Inferences: The Fall of Saigon
children.teaser: Students focus on the skill of inferring.

children.title: Launching the Novel: Character Analysis of Ha
children.teaser: This lesson includes a structure called Numbered Heads Together.

children.title: Reading of the Poem “Inside Out” and Introducing QuickWrites
children.teaser: Review the Think-Pair-Share protocol.

children.title: Considering a Character’s Relationship with Others
children.teaser: Students determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text.

children.title: Getting to Know a Character
children.teaser: Students complete the mid-unit assessment.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge
children.teaser: Students determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development of the text.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge (Continued)
children.teaser: Students work more independently with sections 2-4 of the same article, “The Vietnam Wars.”

children.title: Development of the Plot: Impending Danger and Turmoil
children.teaser: Students again focus on Ha’s experience of and perspective about the events going on around her.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: Vietnam as “Battleground in a Larger Struggle”
children.teaser: Students continue reading and discussing "The Vietnam Wars."

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: The Impending Fall of Saigon
children.teaser: Students continue to work with Section 5 of “The Vietnam Wars.”

children.title: Character Analysis: How Do Personal Possessions Reveal Aspects of Characters?
children.teaser: Students cite the textual evidence that supports analysis of what the text says and inferences drawn.

children.title: Examining How Word Choice Contributes to Tone and Meaning
children.teaser: Students explain how nuances in word meanings contribute to the tone of the poem.

children.title: Comparing Meaning and Tone
children.teaser: Students can make inferences to deepen my understanding of Inside Out & Back Again.

children.title: How Word Choice Contributes to Tone and Meaning
children.teaser: Students cite text-based evidence that provides the strongest support for my analysis of literary text.

children.title: Finding Home: Refugees
children.teaser: Students build knowledge about refugees’ search for a place to call home.

children.title: Collecting Details: The Challenges Ha Faces and Ha as a Dynamic Character
children.teaser: Students continue reading Inside Out & Back Again. Students also focus on Ha’s character and how it changes over the course of the novel.

children.title: Rereading and Close Reading
children.teaser: Rereading and Close Reading: Communism, “The Vietnam Wars,” and “Last Respects” (Pages 85 and 86).

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: Fleeing Saigon as Panic Rises”
children.teaser: Building Background Knowledge: Fleeing Saigon as “Panic Rises.”

children.title: Building Background Knowledge, Predicting, and Focusing on Key Vocabulary
children.teaser: Building Background Knowledge, Predicting, and Focusing on Key Vocabulary: “Refugees: Who, Where, Why.”

children.title: Building Background Knowledge and Summarizing
children.teaser: Building Background Knowledge and Summarizing: “Refugees: Who, Where, Why” Part 2.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge
children.teaser: Building Background Knowledge: Challenges Bosnian Refugees Faced Fleeing and Finding Home.

children.title: Analyzing an Informational Text about a Refugee Experience
children.teaser: Students can determine the meaning of unfamiliar words based on context clues.

children.title: Analyzing the Content of a Model Essay
children.teaser: Students find the gist of a model essay.

children.title: Close Reading: Paragraph 1 of “Refugee and Immigrant Children
children.teaser: Students find the gist of the first paragraph of “Refugee and Immigrant Children: A Comparison.”

children.title: Analyzing the Significance of the Novel’s Title
children.teaser: Students connect the universal refugee experience to Inside Out & Back Again.

children.title: Close Reading: Paragraphs 2 and 3 of “Refugee and Immigrant Children: A Comparison”
children.teaser: Students analyze how specific words, phrases, and sentences help me understand what refugee and immigrant children need for successful adaptation.

children.title: Analyzing the Significance of the Novel’s Title (Part 2)
children.teaser: Students continue to connect the universal refugee experience to Inside Out & Back Again.

children.title: Close Reading: Paragraph 4 of “Refugee and Immigrant Children: A Comparison”
children.teaser: Students can analyze how specific words, phrases, and sentences help me understand what refugee and immigrant children need for successful adaptation.

children.title: Analyzing the Significance of the Novel’s Title
children.teaser: Analyzing the Significance of the Novel’s Title: Connecting the Universal Refugee Experience.

children.title: Connecting Universal Refugee Experience to Inside Out & Back Again
children.teaser: Connecting the Universal Refugee Experience of Fleeing and Finding Home to the Title.

children.title: Planning Introductory and Concluding Paragraphs
children.teaser: Planning the Introductory and Concluding Paragraphs of the End of Unit Assessment Essay.

children.title: Unit 2 Assessment, Part One: First Draft of Analysis Essay
children.teaser: End of Unit 2 Assessment, Part One: First Draft of Analysis Essay.

children.title: Introducing Final Performance Task and Analyzing Statistics
children.teaser: Introducing Final Performance Task and Analyzing Statistics.

children.title: Launching Researching
children.teaser: Launching Researching: Reading for Gist and Gathering Evidence Using the Research Guide.

children.title: End of Unit 2 Assessment, Part Two
children.teaser: Final Draft of Analytical Essay.

children.title: Culminating Project
children.teaser: Students write two research-based poems that reflect “inside out” and “back again”.

children.title: Finishing Who? Where? and Why? Research
children.teaser: Students create a culturally appropriate fictional character profile for their “inside out” poem.

children.title: Analyzing Poems from Inside Out & Back Again
children.teaser: Students describe the criteria of an effective poem.

children.title: Writing Best First Draft of “Inside Out” Poem
children.teaser: Students write “inside out” poem based on factual details about real-life refugees from informational texts.

children.title: Writing Best First Draft of “Back Again” Poem
children.teaser: Students write a poem describing how the narrator refugee, turns “Back Again” as he/she adapts.

children.title: Peer Critique of “Inside Out” and “Back Again” Poems
children.teaser: Peer Critique of “Inside Out” and “Back Again” Poems.

children.title: Revision
children.teaser: Students write a final draft of two poems.

children.title: Working With Evidence:Taking a Stand
children.teaser: Students read text while studying the theme of taking a stand.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: Taking a Stand
children.teaser: Students read speeches given by people who stand up for a cause.

children.title: Launching The Module: Taking a Stand
children.teaser: Students begin to build their background knowledge of what it means to take a stand.

children.title: Taking a Stand: Equal Rights for Women
children.teaser: Lessons that involve close reading will include a new type of supporting material.

children.title: Analyzing Text Structure & Summarizing Text: “Equal Rights for Women”
children.teaser: Students continue to work with Shirley Chisholm’s speech “Equal Rights for Women.”

children.title: Central Idea and Supporting Details: “Equal Rights for Women”
children.teaser: Students engage in a jigsaw.

children.title: Analyzing the Author’s Perspective: “Equal Rights for Women” Shirley Chisholm
children.teaser: Students analyze Shirley Chisholm’s perspective in “Equal Rights for Women.”

children.title: World Cafe: Analyzing Sojourner Truth’s “Ain’t I a Woman?”
children.teaser: The text-dependent questions are based on the Making Evidence-Based Claims units developed by Odell Education.

children.title: Analyzing Excerpts from Lyndon Johnson’s Speech “The Great Society”
children.teaser: If students finish the assessment early, consider having other independent activities they can work on.

children.title: Launching To Kill A Mockingbird
children.teaser: This lesson launches students’ study of To Kill a Mockingbird.

children.title: Analyzing Character: Understanding Atticus
children.teaser: Students write an essay and use evidence and details from the text.

children.title: Analyzing Text Structure: To Kill a Mockingbird (Chapter 2)
children.teaser: Summary writing of To Kill a Mockingbird is introduced in this lesson.

children.title: Focusing on Taking a Stand (Chapter 2 cont.)
children.teaser: Students continue to work with Chapter 2 in this lesson.

children.title: How Literature Draws Themes from the Bible and World Religions
children.teaser: Students also view a short segment of the film version of To Kill a Mockingbird.

children.title: Making Inferences: The Golden Rule and Radley’s Melancholy Little Drama
children.teaser: Students practice writing a summary of a literary work.

children.title: Inferring About Character: Atticus (Chapter 5)
children.teaser: Students engage in Quiz-Quiz-Trade. Introduced in Module 2, Unit 1, Lesson 4.

children.title: Comparing Text Structures: To Kill a Mockingbird, “Those Winter Sundays”
children.teaser: Poem text structure analysis is introduced in this lesson.

children.title: Jigsaw to Analyze Mood, Tone in To Kill a Mockingbird
children.teaser: Remind students to keep in mind other elements of poetry to understand the meaning.

children.title: Text Comparisons: Comparing Text Structures and Text Types (Chapter 9)
children.teaser: Students will practice the comparing and contrasting that they have learned in this unit.

children.title: World Café to Analyze Themes in To Kill a Mockingbird
children.teaser: This lesson focuses on characterization of Atticus in particular.

children.title: Analyzing Author’s Craft in To Kill a Mockingbird
children.teaser: Analyzing how the author uses the allusion to the Golden Rule in a new way.

children.title: Case Study:  Atticus Takes a Stand
children.teaser: Students reflect on the reading by answering focus questions.

children.title: Analyzing How Words and Actions Reveal Character
children.teaser: Students will answer text-dependent questions about Chapters 11, 13 using Three Threes in a Row.

children.title: Text to Film Comparison: Taking a Stand at the Jailhouse
children.teaser: This lesson features the last text to film comparison before the mid-unit assessment.

children.title: Analyzing Themes: The Golden Rule and Taking a Stand
children.teaser: Students discuss the Little Rock Nine photograph in relation to the angry mob scene.

children.title: Text to Film and Perspective Comparison to Kill a Mockingbird
children.teaser: This assessment addresses students’ ability to analyze the novel.

children.title: Fishbowl Comparing Atticus and Mr. Gilmer (Chapters 17-19)
children.teaser: Students will be introduced and participate in a new protocol: Fishbowl.

children.title: Analyzing Word Choice: Atticus’s Closing Speech (Chapters 20-21)
children.teaser: Students will synthesize and refer to the racial prejudice and tension that this trial represents.

children.title: Making Inferences: Analyzing Atticus (Chapters 22-23)
children.teaser: Students continue to analyze Atticus’s character through examples of his dialogue.

children.title: Four Corners: Taking a Stand in To Kill a Mockingbird
children.teaser: Students engage key quotes for the assessment in a Four Corners activity.

children.title: Analyzing the Model Essay
children.teaser: The goal of argument writing is for the reader to acknowledge the validity of the claim.

children.title: Writing an Argument Essay
children.teaser: Students use their Atticus note-catchers  to craft the claim for their argument essay.

children.title: Critique with Rubric, Including Synthesis of Scenes in Previous Chapters
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the Essay Planner at the end of this lesson.

children.title: Writing an Argument Essay: Planning the Essay
children.teaser: Students review the rubric from their essay in Module 1.

children.title: Drafting The Argument Essay
children.teaser: Students write the draft of their essay about Atticus’s decision to defend Tom Robinson.

children.title: Launching the Readers Theater Groups: Allocating Key Quotes and Scenes
children.teaser: One of the key quotes from Lesson 8 is allocated to each Readers Theater group.

children.title: Writing the First Draft of the Readers Theater Script
children.teaser: Students generate criteria of an effective Readers Theater script.

children.title: Revise Essay Drafts
children.teaser: Have independent activities ready for students who finish revising early.

children.title: Taking a Stand in Maycomb
children.teaser: Students write a commentary on how their script is a response To Kill a Mockingbird.

children.title: Readers Theater Scene Selection Justification and Peer Critique
children.teaser: Students can explain how their script develops the main idea of the key quote.

children.title: Managing the Sequence of Events in Our Script
children.teaser: Students continue to work on their Readers' Theatre scripts.

children.title: Readers Theater: Writing a Conclusion
children.teaser: Students orally rehearse a conclusion together before writing.

children.title: Readers Theater Commentary
children.teaser: Students write a commentary about the connections between their script and To Kill a Mockingbird.

children.title: Performance Task: Readers Theater Performance
children.teaser: Students perform Readers Theater script for an audience.

children.title: A Midsummer Night’s Dream and the Comedy of Control
children.teaser: Students read and analyze Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: Understanding Shakespeare and Launching A Midsummer Night’s Dream
children.teaser: Students will begin by studying the universal appeal of Shakespeare’s works.

children.title: The Universal Appeal of Shakespeare, Part 1

children.title: The Authorship of Shakespeare: “The Shakespeare Shakedown”

children.teaser: Students set up “Discussion Appointments” with five peers.

children.title: Analyzing the Central Claim and Supporting Claims: “The Shakespeare Shakedown”
children.teaser: Students engage in a jigsaw on the evidence-based claims in Schama’s article.

children.title: Analyzing Text Structure: “The Shakespeare Shakedown”
children.teaser: Students continue to work with Simon Schama’s article.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Analyzing an Author’s Argument and Text Structure
children.teaser: The Assessment text is excerpted from “The Top Ten Reasons Shakespeare Did Not Write Shakespeare.”

children.title: Launching A Midsummer Night’s Dream: The Universal Appeal of Shakespeare

children.title: Launching A Midsummer Night’s Dream: Identifying the Characters, Settings, Conflicts

children.title: Reading Shakespeare: Understanding Shakespeare’s Language

children.title: Author’s Craft: Analyzing Shakespeare’s Craft: Part 2

children.title: Analyzing the Model Essay: Studying Argument
children.teaser: Students begin the writing process Assessment, an argument essay on A Midsummer Night’s Dream.

children.title: Evaluating the Model and Crafting a Claim
children.teaser: Continue preparing students to write their argument essay for their End of Unit 2 Assessment.

children.title: Analyzing Language, Character, and Theme: World Café Discussion

children.title: Author’s Craft: Poetry and Prose

children.title: Text to Film Comparison: Bottom’s Transformation

children.title: Characters’ Decisions: The Flow of Consequences in Midsummer
children.teaser: Students are think about characters as setting up the flow ofconsequences in the play.

children.title: End of Unit Assessment

children.title: A Midsummer Night’s Dream: Comedy of Control
children.teaser: Students continue to follow the theme of control in A Midsummer Night’s Dream

children.title: Characters and Consequences

children.title: Tracking Control in A Midsummer Night’s Dream

children.title: Analyzing the Resolution of the Play: World Café Discussion

children.title: Analyzing How Shakespeare’s Play Draws upon Greek Mythology: Part 1
children.teaser: Students read the text to gain a deeper understanding of the story.

children.title: Reading Shakespeare: The Play within the Play

children.teaser: Students use their completed narrative structure organizers to write a summary of “Pyramus and Thisbe.”

children.title: Leaving the Play: All’s Well That Ends Well

children.teaser: Analyzing Narrative Structure and Author’s Craft: Part 1

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment
children.teaser: Analyzing Narrative Structure and Author’s Craft: Part 2

children.title: Analyzing the Model Essay: Studying Argument
children.teaser: The argument essay in this module focuses on crafting a clear, logical argument.

children.title: Evaluating the Model and Crafting a Claim
children.teaser: Students prepare to write their argument essay.

children.title: Writing an Argument Essay: Peer Critique
children.teaser: Students review the rubric, which will be used to score their essay.

children.title: Writing an Argument Essay: Planning the Essay
children.teaser: Students start a Writing Improvement Tracker they will return to after writing the essay.

children.title: Drafting the Argument Essay
children.teaser: At this point, students need time to craft their essay.

children.title: Japanese-American Relations during World War II

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: “War in the Pacific,” Part 1

children.teaser: Students analyze how the experience on the raft reveals aspects of Louie’s character.

children.title: Introducing a Thematic Concept in This Unit
children.teaser: Students determine a thematic concept in Unbroken.

children.title: Analyzing a Thematic Concept
children.teaser: Students analyze word relationships used in Unbroken.

children.title: Understanding Perspective
children.teaser: Analyzing how ideas of Japanese society contributed to how Japanese guards treated POW’s during WWII.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: The Internment of Japanese-Americans during WWII, Part 1

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: The Internment of Japanese-Americans during WWII, Part 2

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: The Internment of Japanese-Americans during WWII, Part 3

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: The Internment of Japanese-Americans during WWII, Part 4
children.teaser: Students can explain how World War II affected American society.

children.title: Gathering Textual Evidence: “Invisibility” of Those Interned

children.title: Analyzing Hillenbrand’s Language Techniques

children.title: Character Analysis: Resilience

children.title: Analyzing Theme: The Invisibility of Captives during WWII
children.teaser: Students use a Frayer model to deepen their understanding of words in Unbroken.

children.title: Analyzing Evidence: Writing about Theme
children.teaser: Analyzing Evidence: Writing about Theme

children.title: Informational Essay Planning: Essay Rubric and Planner
children.teaser: Students identify strategies and resources to help me spell correctly on my informational essay.

children.title: End of Unit Assessment, Part 1: Best First Draft of an Informational Essay
children.teaser: Students write an informational essay using relevant details from texts that are selected and organized.

children.title: Introducing a Thematic Concept: Becoming Visible Again after Captivity
children.teaser: Students analyze nuances in word meanings.

children.title: Analyzing a Thematic Concept: Becoming Visible after Captivity (pages 334–344)

children.title: End of Unit Assessment: Revising the Informative Essay
children.teaser: Students can use feedback from others to revise, edit, and improve their essay.

children.title: Becoming Visible Again: Finding Freedom and Recovering Life

children.title: Analyzing a Thematic Concept: Becoming Visible Again
children.teaser: Students explain the general function of verbals (gerunds, participles, infinitives) and their function in sentences.

children.title: Launching the Performance Task: Thematic Statement & Narrative Prompt
children.teaser: Students explain the use of verbals in sentences in Unbroken.

children.title: Researching Miné Okubo: Gathering Textual Evidence
children.teaser: Students gather evidence about Miné Okubo’s life from informational texts for their narrative.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Planning the Plot
children.teaser: Students understand the rubric for the narrative writing performance task.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Planning Narrative Techniques
children.teaser: Students continue to plan their performance task (Narrative Writing: Becoming Visible Again after Internment).

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Single Draft Narrative
children.teaser: Students write an on-demand, single-draft narrative based on a moment in Miné Okubo’s life.

children.title: End of Unit Assessment: Analysis of Language Techniques
children.teaser: Students also write book reviews for their independent reading books.

children.title: Final Performance Task: Becoming Visible Again
children.teaser: Students complete a self-assessment using the Narrative Writing: Becoming Visible Again after Internment rubric.

children.title: Close Reading: Understanding Carlotta’s Journey
children.teaser: Students continue to add to the Journey to Justice note-catcher throughout Units 1 and 2.

children.title: Understanding Brown v. Board of Education’s Impact on Carlotta’s Journey

children.title: Advantages and Disadvantages of Various Mediums: The Montgomery Bus Boycott Speech

children.title: Close Reading: The Montgomery Bus Boycott Speech

children.title: Analyzing Language in a Speech: The Montgomery Bus Boycott Speech
children.teaser: Students study the difference between the two voices and consider how their use affects meaning.

children.title: Analyzing the Power of Different Mediums: Little Rock Girl 1957

children.title: Analyzing the Power of Different Mediums: A Mighty Long Way

children.title: Analyzing Different Mediums: Advantages and Disadvantages
children.teaser: Students continue evaluating the advantages and disadvantages of different mediums, focusing this lesson on text.

children.title: Analyzing Events: Carlotta’s Journey
children.teaser: Students participate in a Chalk Talk this lesson to continue their analysis of Carlotta’s journey.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Classifying and Evaluating Primary Sources
children.teaser: Students look at primary sources to evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using different mediums.

children.title: Analyzing Author’s Craft: “I Have a Dream”

children.title: Language Analysis: “I Have a Dream”
children.teaser: Students focus on Dr. King’s use of active and passive voice, learned in Lesson 6.

children.title: Informational Essay Planning: Studying the Essay Prompt and Gathering Evidence
children.teaser: Students will study the informational essay prompt.

children.title: Informational Essay Planning: Analyzing and Selecting Evidence
children.teaser: Analyzing evidence, collected on their Gathering Evidence note-catchers and select the strongest evidence to include.

children.title: Informational Essay Planning: Essay Rubric and Essay Planner
children.teaser: Students prepare to write their end of unit assessment essay.

children.title: Best First Draft of an Informational Essay
children.teaser: Students are asked not only to think about writing, but also how they use language.

children.title: Analyzing an Author’s Craft: Carlotta’s Journey to Justice
children.teaser: Students deconstruct the word “dignity” and analyze the strategies Carlotta used to maintain her dignity.

children.title: Analyzing an Author’s Craft: Carlotta’s Journey to Justice
children.teaser: This opening is the first of a three-lesson series which students focus on language skills.

children.title: Revising the Informational Essay
children.teaser: Students revise and edit their End of Unit 2 Assessment based on your feedback.

children.title: Bringing the Journey to Life
children.teaser: Students finish reading A Mighty Long Way and complete their study of Carlotta’s journey to justice.

children.title: Analyzing a Central Idea: Carlotta’s Journey to Justice
children.teaser: Students learn about verbals: gerunds, participles, and infinitives

children.title: Launching the Performance Task
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the Performance Task Prompt and hear a model presentation.

children.title: Analysis of Language Techniques
children.teaser: This assessment is the culmination of students’ study of voice, mood, and word choice.

children.title: Choosing Songs for the Film Soundtrack
children.teaser: Students need to listen to the four songs they were exposed to across the module.

children.title: On-Demand Writing—Photograph and Song Choices for a Film
children.teaser: Students receive feedback from the Mid-Unit 3 Assessments.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Single-Draft Narrative
children.teaser: Using Writing to Make Prompt Cards

children.title: End of Unit Assessment: Analysis of Language Techniques
children.teaser: Practicing Presentations

children.title: Final Performance Task: Snapshot in a Journey
children.teaser: Presentation of Photograph and Song Selections

children.title: Sustainability of the US Food Supply Chain
children.teaser: Students will read Michael Pollan’s The Omnivore’s Dilemma.

children.title: Analyzing Author’s Purpose and Evaluating Claims in The Omnivore’s Dilemma
children.teaser: Students analyze authors’ and speakers’ purposes and evaluate the claims they make.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: What IS the Omnivore’s Dilemma Anyway?
children.teaser: This first lesson is designed to hook students into the book The Omnivore’s Dilemma.

children.title: Reading for Gist and Answering Text-Dependent Questions
children.teaser: Industrial Food Chain

children.title: Analyzing Author’s Purpose: Industrial Food Chain
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the Author’s Purpose graphic organizer.

children.title: Determining Author’s Purpose: Industrial Food Chain
children.teaser: Working in pairs and triads students answer text-dependent questions.

children.title: Industrial Organic Food Chain
children.teaser: Students build background knowledge about Michael Pollan’s industrial organic food chain.

children.title: Analyzing a Speaker’s Purpose and Motives of a Media Excerpt
children.teaser: Students consider a speaker’s purpose in preparation for the mid-unit assessment.

children.title: Analyzing Author’s Purpose in Speech and Text
children.teaser: Students listen to a speech by 11-year-old Birke Baehr and take notes.

children.title: Local Sustainable Food Chain
children.teaser: Students build knowledge about Michael Pollan’s local sustainable food chain.

children.title: The Polyface Local Sustainable Farm
children.teaser: Introduction to Evaluating an Argument graphic organizer, used in the end of unit assessment.

children.title: Reading for the Gist and Answering Text-Dependent Questions
children.teaser: Hunter-Gatherer Food Chain

children.title: Evaluating an Argument: The Joy of Hunting
children.teaser: Read the Interview with an Organic Farmer.

children.title: Making a Claim and Advocating Persuasively
children.teaser: Preparing for the Practice Fishbowl

children.title: Advocating Persuasively in a Fishbowl: Practice
children.teaser: Students peer critique during the Fishbowls; ensure they are familiar with the Peer Critique protocol.

children.title: Evaluating Arguments and Claims
children.teaser: Assess student responses for end of unit 1 assessment using NYS 2-Point Rubric—Short Response.

children.title: Advocating Persuasively in a Fishbowl
children.teaser: Assess each student using the Advocating Persuasively Checklist Rubric.

children.title: Researching Consequences and Stakeholders of Michael Pollan’s Four Food Chains
children.teaser: Students use The Omnivore’s Dilemma identifying consequences of the food chains.

children.title: Determining Cascading Consequences Using The Omnivore’s Dilemma: Industrial Food Chain
children.teaser: Students learn how to create a Cascading Consequences chart.

children.title: Preparing for Further Research: Industrial Food Chain
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the research process.

children.title: Further Research: Industrial Food Chain
children.teaser: Students extend their research.

children.title: Adding to Cascading Consequences and Stakeholders: Industrial Food Chain
children.teaser: Students are introduced to stakeholders who are affected by the consequences.

children.title: Cascading Consequences Using The Omnivore’s Dilemma
children.teaser: This is the first of three lessons focused on the industrial organic food chain.

children.title: Using Search Terms for Further Research
children.teaser: Industrial Organic Food Chain

children.title: Adding to Cascading Consequences and Stakeholders: Industrial Organic Food Chain
children.teaser: This lesson contains a refresher of when to use citations and the proper format.

children.title: Determining Cascading Consequences Using The Omnivore’s Dilemma
children.teaser: Cascading Consequences: Local Sustainable Food Chain

children.title: Further Research: Local Sustainable Food Chain
children.teaser: Students practice research skills before the mid-unit assessment.

children.title: Adding to Cascading Consequences and Stakeholders: Local Sustainable Food Chain
children.teaser: Students analyze and create an anchor chart for effective speaking skills.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Research Simulation
children.teaser: Students continue their research for the final food chain.

children.title: Cascading Consequences: The Omnivore’s Dilemma
children.teaser: Review the Hunter-Gatherer Food Chain Cascading Consequences chart

children.title: Further Research: Hunter-Gatherer Food Chain
children.teaser: This lesson provides students a final opportunity to practice researching, without introducing new skills.

children.title: Adding to Cascading Consequences and Stakeholders: Hunter-Gatherer Food Chain
children.teaser: Students consider consequences and stakeholders of food chains.

children.title: Writing a Position Speech: Which Food Chain Would Be Best?
children.teaser: Students watch the Birke Baehr speech once more.

children.title: Creating a Visual Component for the Speech
children.teaser: End of Unit Assessment Preparation and Practice

children.title: End of Unit Assessment: Presentation of Position
children.teaser: Students present their position speeches.

children.title: Writing a Position Paper
children.teaser: Which four food chains would you choose to feed the United States?

children.title: Analyzing a Model Position Paper
children.teaser: Students will use the evidence they gathered in Unit 2 to write their position paper.

children.title: Planning Body Paragraphs of Position Paper
children.teaser: Using the Quote Sandwich organizer to plan Body Paragraphs 2, 3 of their position paper.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Draft of Position Paper
children.teaser: Students draft introductory and concluding paragraphs of their End of Unit 3 Assessment position paper.

children.title: Introducing the Performance Task Prompt and Beginning a Visual Representation
children.teaser: In this lesson, you introduce the performance task.

children.title: End of Unit Assessment: Final Position Paper
children.teaser: Assess final position papers using the Position Paper Rubric.

children.title: Final Performance Task
children.teaser: Sharing Visual Representations of Position Papers

children.title: Developing Core Proficiencies Curriculum
children.teaser: These units model instruction and provide flexible materials to use and adapt for a variety of contexts.

children.title: Reading Closely for Textual Details Units
children.teaser: "And, above all, we had to learn English"

children.title: Island of hope, island of tears
children.teaser: Students analyze visual-based texts.

children.title: Families have been divided…
children.teaser: Students read and analyze informational texts.

children.title: A string of human beads…
children.teaser: Students read, analyze, and compare texts.

children.title: First step on the new soil
children.teaser: Students read and analyze three related texts.

children.title: So we have crossed half the world for this!
children.teaser: Students learn the characteristics of an effective text-based discussion.

children.title: Making Evidence-Based Claims
children.teaser: Sojourner Truth, Shirley Chisholm, and Venus Williams

children.title: Out of Kilter
children.teaser: Students learn the elements of making evidence-based claims.

children.title: Do You Type?
children.teaser: Students develop the ability to make evidence-based claims.

children.title: Centre Court
children.teaser: Students organize evidence to develop and expand claims.

children.title: The Wrong Side of History
children.teaser: Students express evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: This Situation is Outrageous
children.teaser: Students express global evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: Researching to Deepen Understanding
children.teaser: Human-Animal Interaction

children.title: Initiating Inquiry
children.teaser: By the end of Part 1, students will have identified an Area of Investigation and developed Inquiry Questions.

children.title: Gathering Information
children.teaser: By the end of Part 2, students will have assessed the main common sources and gathered notes about the information in the texts.

children.title: Deepening Understanding
children.teaser: By the end of Part 3, students will have a series of evidence-based claims addressing their Inquiry Questions.

children.title: Finalizing Inquiry
children.teaser: By the end of Part 4, students will have an analyzed body of research addressing their Inquiry Questions from which to develop and communicate an evidence- based perspective on the Area of Investigation.

children.title: Developing And Communicating An Evidence-Based Perspective
children.teaser: By the end of Part 5, students will have an organized body of research and have written an evidence-based perspective on the Area of Investigation.

children.title: Building Evidence-Based Arguments
children.teaser: "E Pluribus Unum"

children.title: Nearly everyone agrees that America's immigration system is broken; what they don't agree on is how to fix it.
children.teaser: Students understand an issue as a context for various perspectives, positions, and arguments.

children.title: Immigration reform is our best chance to increaseAmerica's economic dynamism.
children.teaser: Students analyze the position, evidence, and perspective of arguments.

children.title: The time has come when we should shut the door and keep what we have
children.teaser: Students evaluate arguments and synthesize what they have learned.

children.title: On immigration, the evidence is overwhelming; the best way forward is clear.
children.teaser: Students establish evidence-based claims as a premises for a logical argument.

children.title: What do I know?
children.teaser: For students, writing is a key means of asserting and defending claims, showing what they know about a subject, and conveying what they have experienced, imagined, thought, and felt.
